job_title: Library Specialist II in Corpus Christi, TX
pros: The university is a pretty relaxed environment, my coworkers and supervisors are very respectful. Our departments very often try to make sure that we are including everyone in our activities, and that we respect the cultures and ideas of all of our students. The work isn’t too hard and the office culture is pretty relaxed. Supervisors also encourage continuing learning and even supporting moving up when you obtain higher skill levels. Benefits are great, so much more holidays and paid time off compared to every other job I’ve had. The work/life balance is great, the schedule is not set in stone, and is very open to accommodate me within reason. My supervisors are very good to me, I’m not sure if other places on campus are like this, but thankfully mine are. Eventually I will have to leave for better pay, but I will always be thankful for the best environment I’ve ever worked in.
cons: The main con is that the pay isn’t livable when alone. That isn’t a problem for some, but it will be if you’re the sole source of income.

review_title: Incredibly convenient while attending school and a great life experience.
job_title: Biomedical Media Prep Worker in Corpus Christi, TX
pros:
Working at the same place you attend college is incredibly convenient.  Saves on gas and, if you have access to a lounge or mini-fridge/microwave, you save a large amount of money on food and drinks because you can bring your own!  Between work, classes, and studying, I was on campus a minimum of 8 hours a day and having access to an office and locker to put my textbooks and other things, computer and printer access, and mini-fridge/microwave saved me a lot of money, time, and stress!  Being able to run up to the office between classes to drop off notes/books and grab what you need for the next class was incredibly handy.

My position involved me working in a teaching lab in the Life Sciences Dept. and the experience has been highly beneficial.  It has helped me focus on how much lab time I really want in my future career and really get involved with hands-on skills needed in my field.

Regular interaction with professors allows them to get to know you and you end up receiving many offers for letters of recommendation if you do your job well with the right attitude.

Being a workstudy requires you to be a student and they are flexible with your course load and schedule.  You're a student first!
cons:
As a workstudy, you receive minimum wage and can only work a maximum of 19 hrs/week, or 38 hrs/pay period (every 2 weeks).

Additionally, as a workstudy, you are not considered staff, which means no benefits.  Although, as a student you can still sign up separately through the Texas A&M system for a Student Insurance Plan. 

My job and studies required me to be inside all day.

review_title: Beautiful campus. Many good people. But watch out for the upper administration.
job_title: Public Relations and Marketing in Corpus Christi, TX
pros: A growing university that seeks to stretch its reach beyond the small city of Corpus Christi, Texas. A very pleasant campus that wins over prospective students by its location.
cons: Upper administration is the worst I've come across, after having been at four other universities in my 30-year career. Very negative leadership that starts at the top. Focus of upper administrators is on coercing the local community to "love" their leader and not be focused on undertaking major research, recruiting beyond the state and, basically, acting like a "big league" university. This place is not one for any university professional who has experienced larger, more complex and nationally-focused universities. All those who come from major universities don't last long because the upper administration is only focused on looking good for the smaller community, rather than serving the state and nation. And if anyone outshines any of the upper administrators, then he/she is sent packing. I lasted five years and saw the revolving door sweep out the best and brightest.

job_title: Professor in Corpus Christi, TX

job_title: Research Assistant in Corpus Christi, TX
pros: Always above minimum wage (at least until Texas reaches $10/hour), flexible schedules to work around classes, most jobs are for Teachers Assistants or Graders, but be on the lookout for more Career options in Research Labs and Administration, as well as Marketing / Social Media offices.
cons: Always part-time work, and it's not guaranteed to continue after the semester if you get a basic student-worker job and not something in a Research Lab or main / administration office. No real benefits to students other than pay as a student worker.

review_title: This was a great experience and learning opportunity for me.
job_title: Supplemental Instructor in Corpus Christi, TX
pros:
The work balance enabled me to prepare for my teaching duties while still having time for my regular classes and social life. 

The pay was decent for the amount of work and the support from my supervisor was excellent as well as the opportunity it gave me to work closely with faculty.
cons: I though that the mandatory training that they made us do was a waste of time for everyone involved. Every person is different and has different teaching styles and we were all excellent students which is why we had the job in the first place. It might be better to look at the 'training' more like 'orientation' as oppose to the type of training you might get to be a derrickman for an oil company for example.

review_title: my experience at TAMUCC was exciting. motivating, and a one of a kind opportunity.

review_title: Great beaches, not so great salary
job_title: Academic Advisor in San Antonio, TX
pros: The campus is literally on the beach so there is ALWAYS beautiful scenery even on the bad weather days. It's a small campus so everything is less than 10 minutes walk and it is very safe. Campus police patrol the campus 24/7 and are also stationed on the campus so there is rarely anything amiss. The student body and the physical campus are growing and there is lots of activity happening in and around the campus and the greater city community. Most of the people are great and the city generally loves the campus and students.
cons: Because of the exponential growth, the university is experiencing many growing pains evident in lack of student housing, parking, and increased workload. Faculty, staff, and administrators have been in their roles for literal decades so they are not always open to change (i.e. updating processes or technology). The low pay for staff was also an issue given the pricey housing in the area. There was also not a lot of support for university sports or activities, the town loves the university but from afar and doesn't really get engaged with things going on.

review_title: Great colleagues, but a lot of bureaucracy
